race.name: Reliance Tennessee Gravel
race.tagline: Appalachian foothills gravel in remote southeast Tennessee.

climate.description: Variable conditions with heat possible in spring, cool possible in fall, and humidity.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Appalachian foothills. Moderate to challenging elevation with forest and mountain scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional Tennessee event. Appalachian foothills terrain is nice but remote location and limited organization.

biased_opinion.summary: Reliance Tennessee Gravel is a regional event in remote southeast Tennessee near Cherokee National Forest. The Appalachian foothills terrain offers moderate to challenging climbing with forest scenery, but the remote location, limited amenities, and moderate organization keep it firmly in Tier 3. Reliance is a small community with limited lodging and dining. It's a solid regional event for Tennessee cyclists.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional Tennessee gravel race with Appalachian foothills terrain. Worth it for Tennessee cyclists seeking a remote adventure. Not a destination race for out-of-state travelers.

final_verdict.one_liner: Remote Appalachian foothills gravel in southeast Tennessee.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in Tennessee and want a remote Appalachian adventure—yes, it's a solid regional event. If you're from out of state—there are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Southeast events: Gravel Worlds, Pisgah Monster-Cross, Hot Springs Gravel Gauntlet. For similar regional events: other Tennessee gravel races.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Reliance has very limited lodging. Cleveland or Chattanooga have more options.
logistics.food: Small community with limited dining. Stock nutrition.

course_description.character: Appalachian foothills gravel with moderate to challenging climbing.
course_description.signature_challenge: Appalachian foothills climbing in remote southeast Tennessee.

non_negotiables.why: Appalachian foothills require solid climbing fitness.
Tennessee spring/fall means heat and humidity are possible.
Remote location requires self-sufficiency and preparation.

topics.heat: Racing in Tennessee heat and humidity

marketplace_variables.race_hook: Appalachian foothills gravel in remote southeast Tennessee.
marketplace_variables.race_hook_detail: Regional event near Cherokee National Forest.

logistics.explanation: Free parking at Hiwassee Outfitters with camping available on-site, but camping is first-come first-served in a small area. The warning not to park at the adjacent boat ramp suggests ongoing coordination challenges with local facilities.

length.explanation: Saturday's 65-72 mile race with 8,700 feet of climbing hits the gravel sweet spot, while the combined weekend format delivers 15,000+ feet over two days. Multiple distance options from 25-50 miles daily give non-racers actual choices instead of token participation. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar. As Mike puts it: "Sometimes you do an event or go to a race that reminds you why you enjoy the bike so much."

technicality.explanation: Cherokee National Forest routes require slowing down on Sunday's rocky descents, with hardtails recommended for the bumpier terrain. No course marking means GPX navigation is mandatory through 60-90% gravel surfaces that explicitly promise 'no champagne gravel.' Similar technical demands to Gravel Worlds. As Carey Lowery puts it: "Saturday's course was burly: 66 miles and 9200 feet. And with a good bit of chunky gravel/double track, my 2016 Niner RKT RDO with 2.2 Race Kings was the right bike for the gnar..."

elevation.explanation: Named climbs Buck Bald and Starr Mountain anchor Saturday's 8,700 feet of climbing in 65 miles. The combined weekend racing totals around 15,000 feet, which one rider described as '12 hours over 2 days with 15,000+ feet of climbing.' Similar elevation profile to Gravel Worlds. As Carey Lowery puts it: "Saturday's course was burly: 66 miles and 9200 feet. And with a good bit of chunky gravel/double track, my 2016 Niner RKT RDO with 2.2 Race Kings was the right bike for the gnar..."

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 82°F and lows of 63°F, with a 45% chance of rain on any given day. April in eastern Tennessee provides no historical weather data in the research, leaving riders to gamble on conditions. The grassroots nature means minimal weather contingency planning compared to larger events. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego. As Carey Lowery puts it: "With a good bit of chunky gravel/double track, my 2016 Niner RKT RDO with 2.2 Race Kings was the right bike for the gnar."

altitude.explanation: Starting at Hiwassee Outfitters near Chattanooga puts you close to sea level in Tennessee hill country. Even the highest climbs on Buck Bald and Starr Mountain won't trigger altitude concerns for anyone who's driven through moderate elevation. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Two-day format with camping creates proper gravel adventure vibes in Cherokee National Forest. Routes promise 'amazing scenery' with no flat roads through terrain one rider called 'the most beautiful of places to ride a bike.'

prestige.explanation: Grassroots event capped at 250 riders that benefits SORBA Chattanooga, not some corporate gravel series. The tagline explicitly sets expectations for 'grassroots camaraderie' over competitive prestige or pro field depth.

race_quality.explanation: Well-stocked aid stations at key checkpoints like Buck Bald and Starr Mountain tops, but no course marking requires downloaded GPX files. The two-day cumulative time format works smoothly with separate podiums for all categories.

experience.explanation: Post-race amenities include live music, food, beer, and medals for two-day finishers at the base camp setup. One rider summarized it as 'beautiful country, great crowd, good times' in the grassroots atmosphere. As Mike puts it: "I've never experienced a race like this. It was so beautiful and so much fun and I'm anxious to go back and try to do better."

community.explanation: Small 250-rider cap creates intimate camping atmosphere where the tagline promises 'grassroots camaraderie' over corporate polish. SORBA Chattanooga benefits from proceeds, putting entry fees toward trail advocacy instead of profit margins.

field_depth.explanation: Five race categories with cash prizes three deep and free entry for winners indicates modest competitive field size. The 250-rider cap and southeastern location suggests regional participation rather than national draw. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100. As Carey Lowery puts it: "The start was faster than my legs wanted to go this early on, but I knew I needed to hang on to enjoy the draft going up Childer's Creek and Power House Road."

value.explanation: Two days of racing with included camping, free swag (water bottles, pint glasses, bandanas), and cash prizes for podium finishers. Winners get free entry next year, putting money back into participants' pockets.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $60-100. Free parking and included camping at Hiwassee Outfitters keeps accommodation costs minimal. East Tennessee location means reasonable driving distance for Southeast riders without expensive flights or lodging. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

unsplash_photos.description: a bunch of rocks that are laying on the ground
Close-up of a gravel and dirt ground texture

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: IRC Boken Double Cross
primary.why: Underrated mixed-terrain tire. Fast center with confident shoulder grip.

primary.name: Pirelli Cinturato Gravel M
primary.why: Mixed-terrain specialist. Balanced grip and speed for variable conditions.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

videos.title: Gravel Events You Should Know About: SE USA Volume 2
videos.description:
Gravel Cycling Events that you should know about, Southeastern USA, Volume 2.

Not Corporate, Not Expensive, in what we like to call around here, 100% legit grass roots, not just calling themselves grass roots. More to come soon from other regions of the USA, and possibly outside of the USA. Stay tuned...

Enjoy - JOM, Founder of Gravel Cyclist

Chapters:
0:00 Introduction
0:42 Southeast Gravel Series - North & South Carolina
1:23 Skratch Ankle - Milton, Florida
1:53 Fried Clay 200K - Eatonton, Georgia
2:48 Spaghetti 100 - Miccosukee, Florida
3:34 Piggy's Revenge - Venice, Florida
4:15 Rule of Three - Bentonville, Arkansas
4:56 Arkansas Graveler - Mena, Arkansas
5:30 Arkansas High Country Race - Russellville, Arkansas
6:16 Chinkapin Hollow - Fayetteville, Arkansas
6:45 Croatan Buck Fifty - Cape Carteret, North Carolina
7:20 Transylvania Productions - Holly Shelter GG & Uwharrie Forest GG, North Carolina
8:09 Dirt Diggler - Hendersonville, North Carolina
8:35 Gosh Darn Gravel Gathering - Hickman County, Tennessee
9:08 Hardford 50 & Harderford 75 - Hartford, Tennessee
9:35 Reliance Deep Woods Gravel Grinder
10:15 Closing
11:20 General Madness

videos.curation_reason: Recent comprehensive guide to southeastern gravel events by established cycling channel with good views.

key_challenges.name: Bridge area
key_challenges.description: Dangerous section where crashes can occur, resulting in serious injuries including concussions and shoulder damage.

key_challenges.name: 7% grade climb
key_challenges.description: Sustained climb with riders going 7 miles per hour on this challenging grade.

terrain_notes.text: Tar surfaces can be slick if there's moisture on them, requiring caution on descents.

gear_mentions.text: Continental tubeless tires in 28mm width are being used by riders.

additional_quotes.text: Well, we just had one of our team members crash. Probably got a mild concussion. He just crashed on this bridge I'm about to video going across. We're here at the famous Reliance Tennessee Web Brothers store. It's kind of a staple up here. It's only store up here.

rider_intel.search_text: The Reliance Tennessee gravel race features challenging terrain including dangerous bridge sections where crashes resulting in concussions and shoulder injuries have occurred. The course includes sustained climbs with 7% grades where riders slow to 7 miles per hour. Surface conditions can be hazardous, particularly tar sections that become slick when wet. The Web Brothers store serves as a key landmark and appears to be the only store in the area, making it an important logistical point. Riders are using Continental tubeless tires in 28mm widths for the varied terrain. The scenic route passes through beautiful areas that are popular with motorcycles and connects to areas like Cage Cove. The challenging nature of the course requires careful attention to technical descents and sustained climbing efforts.
